Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was sitting on the edge of the bed, still in my work boots, when my husband called. His voice trembled as he told me about the ultimatum his boss had given him—take on a risky project or risk being sidelined. He needed me, not just to listen, but to help him sort through the fear and uncertainty. I could hear the desperation in his words, and I wanted nothing more than to be the steady anchor he needed. But just as I opened my mouth to respond, the piercing site alarm blared through the trailer walls. My heart jumped. Protocol was clear: drop everything, evacuate, and account for every team member. My supervisor’s voice crackled over the radio, barking orders. I was torn—my husband’s pain on one end, my responsibility to my crew on the other. The phone felt heavy in my hand as I stood frozen, caught between the person I loved and the job that demanded my immediate attention.
